question: Question_02_(b)
sols:
See the second hint for how each limit translates into a feature of the
graph.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Your graph can do whatever it wants to the left of \emph{x = -1}, so
  long as it approaches the point \emph{(-1,0)}. The simplest (yet
  somewhat boring) way to achieve this is by setting the function to
  \emph{0} for \emph{x \textless{} -1}.
\item
  Between \emph{x = -1} and \emph{x = 1} the function has to fall from
  $\infty$ to $-\infty$.
\item
  To the right of \emph{x = 1} the function has to come back from
  $-\infty$ and then can do whatever you want it to do.
\end{enumerate}

There is a lot of freedom in how your graph may look, but as long as you
follow the key points above your graph will be correct. Below is our
example \emph{(the purple lines represent asymptotes)}:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math110_April2013_Question2b_solution.jpg}
\end{description}
hints:
What does it mean when a limit evaluates to a number? To infinity? Each
limit listed above turns into a graph feature like a point or asymptote.

Each limit translates into the following graph feature:

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Approaching \emph{x = -1} from the left, the graph approaches the
  point \emph{(-1,0)}.
\item
  There is a vertical asymptote at \emph{x = -1} and the function
  increases to $\infty$ as it approaches \emph{x = -1} from the right.
\item
  There is a vertical asymptote at \emph{x = 1} and the function
  decreases to $-\infty$ as it approaches \emph{x = 1} from either side.
\end{enumerate}
